narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Attended class live each week!
Class discussion, going over homework, talking about papers
We also engaged in more seminar-style discussions in breakout rooms on Zoom.
none

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about computational modeling and the considerations that go into choosing and evaluating models. We also covered models of risk-taking, reinforcement learning, and happiness. I learned to collect data online for the first time. We ended with a final project where we created a psych task, collected online data, analyzed the data, and created a new model to answer our questions.

How computational models are used in neuroscience and psychology research. We learned about and coded models of prospect theory, reinforcement learning and a happiness model from prod Rutledges research. There isnt much math thats taught though - its just very hands on data analysis. Felt more like an applied research methods class than seminar.

I learned, on a practical level, how to generate a behavioral research study, from conceptualization to execution and analysis. In addition to these skills, I gained a deeper understanding of the mathematical and statistical applications of behavioral psychology theorems.
Learned much more on matlab and many interesting behavioral models, including Daniel kahnemans prospect theory

This class provided me insight into how behavioral data can be analyzed to yield new explanations for human behavior. I learnt about how computational models can be used to describe aspects of human behavior such as an individual's risk-taking tendencies. I learnt how to analyze data in MATLAB, and also how to visualize data in many different forms of data visualization. I also learnt how to design an experiment, collect data online on Prolific, analyze the data collected and summarize in a lab report.
How to perform a research study

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was really great overall! No real complaints. The final project at the end was a little rushed just because there were a lot of steps involved, but it was mostly okay. Even though homework was due the night after lecture, it was manageable and not a rush.
More in depth explanation of the models in class and start the final project earlier in the course. Psets were a perfect level of difficulty and reasonable length.
The course was very challenging and engaging! I would have preferred a timeslot that met later in the day, given the timezone difference required getting up at dawn to attend class.

Great course. I think going over some living coding in class (like 15 min) could have definitely helped, or posting hw solutions possibly a week after the hw is due so we could see how you would write the code

The course material was very interesting, and I had great discussions with the professor and the other students, who were all very passionate and engaged. The course material provided a comprehensive understanding of how computational models are created and used in psychological research. The course was also structured well, since it allowed us to build our knowledge of models. One way this course can be improved is by suggesting additional resources to learn MATLAB, since the class does not teach how to use MATLAB extensively. Additionally, this course could be improved by making the problem sets due later in the week, since some problem sets were difficult to do in the time given.
The professor was really helpful and supportive. However, I belive that one should have been given more time to complete the assignments since they were extremely hard

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the class seminar was great. Everyone was very much engaged and interested

Although it was difficult to learn computational modelling online, the break-out rooms and use of Zoom to screenshare and share Powerpoints all helped my understanding of the topic. Recording the lecture was also helpful since it was helpful to re-watch the lecture for key points I may have missed.
this class was easy to learn and follow even though it was full taught remotely

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely recommend! This course was a lot of fun, Professor Rutledge was really amazing and helpful, I got to know my peers, and I can say that I've learned a lot through the whole thing. The final project at the end of the semester required a lot of thought and applying what we learned through the semester, but I enjoyed the whole thing.

Yes if you like coding and are curious about using computational models for research. Its not an advanced machine learning course as its focused on highly interpretable theory-driven models. Was overall quite hard for undergrads but Rutledge is very fair and supportive. Matlab is the programming language which was easy to use but not very popular outside of scientific research.

Yes! I would recommend it to a student seeking an experience that is both challenging and informative, especially with respect to gaining practical skills in making computational research studies. The professor is also wonderful!
Highly recommend! Rob is so great, and the class is just wonderful for learning in general, especially if you want to get some matlab experience

I would highly recommend this course to another student that wants to learn and engage with cutting-edge data analytic techniques. This class teaches you how to think critically about models and how best to approach and analyze behavioral data to answer interesting questions about human behavior.

I would recommend this course to someone that has great experience in research and more advanced coding knowledge than just CS 112. The professor was great and really helpful but the course is extremely tough and one has a very limited amount of time to complete the assignments.
